play.title: The First Part of Henry the Fourth

stagedir.dir: Enter the King Henry, Lord John of Lancaster, Earl of Westmorland, Sir Walter Blunt, with others.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of old sack, and unbuttoning thee after supper, and sleeping upon benches after noon, that thou hast forgotten to demand that truly which thou wouldest truly know. What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the day? Unless hours were cups of sack, and minutes capons, and clocks the tongues of bawds, and dials the signs of leaping-houses, and the blessed sun himself a fair hot wench in flame-color’d taffata; I see no reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand the time of the day.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Indeed you come near me now, Hal, for we that take purses go by the moon and the seven stars, and not by Phoebus, he, “that wand’ring knight so fair.” And I prithee, sweet wag, when thou art a king, as, God save thy Grace—Majesty I should say, for grace thou wilt have none—

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What, none?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No, by my troth, not so much as will serve to be prologue to an egg and butter.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Well, how then? Come, roundly, roundly.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Marry, then, sweet wag, when thou art king, let not us that are squires of the night’s body be call’d thieves of the day’s beauty. Let us be Diana’s foresters, gentlemen of the shade, minions of the moon, and let men say we be men of good government, being govern’d, as the sea is, by our noble and chaste mistress the moon, under whose countenance we steal.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thou sayest well, and it holds well too, for the fortune of us that are the moon’s men doth ebb and flow like the sea, being govern’d, as the sea is, by the moon. As, for proof, now: a purse of gold most resolutely snatch’d on Monday night and most dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning; got with swearing “Lay by,” and spent with crying “Bring in”; now in as low an ebb as the foot of the ladder, and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the gallows.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: By the Lord, thou say’st true, lad. And is not my hostess of the tavern a most sweet wench?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: As the honey of Hybla, my old lad of the castle. And is not a buff jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: How now, how now, mad wag? What, in thy quips and thy quiddities? What a plague have I to do with a buff jerkin?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Why, what a pox have I to do with my hostess of the tavern?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, thou hast call’d her to a reckoning many a time and oft.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No, I’ll give thee thy due, thou hast paid all there.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Yea, and elsewhere, so far as my coin would stretch, and where it would not, I have us’d my credit.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, and so us’d it that, were it not here apparent that thou art heir apparent—But I prithee, sweet wag, shall there be gallows standing in England when thou art king? And resolution thus fubb’d as it is with the rusty curb of old father antic the law? Do not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: No, thou shalt.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Shall I? O rare! By the Lord, I’ll be a brave judge.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thou judgest false already. I mean thou shalt have the hanging of the thieves, and so become a rare hangman.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, Hal, well, and in some sort it jumps with my humor as well as waiting in the court, I can tell you.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: For obtaining of suits?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, for obtaining of suits, whereof the hangman hath no lean wardrobe. ’Sblood, I am as melancholy as a gib cat or a lugg’d bear.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Or an old lion, or a lover’s lute.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What sayest thou to a hare, or the melancholy of Moor-ditch?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thou hast the most unsavory similes and art indeed the most comparative, rascalliest, sweet young prince. But, Hal, I prithee trouble me no more with vanity; I would to God thou and I knew where a commodity of good names were to be bought. An old lord of the Council rated me the other day in the street about you, sir, but I mark’d him not, and yet he talk’d very wisely, but I regarded him not, and yet he talk’d wisely, and in the street too.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thou didst well, for wisdom cries out in the streets, and no man regards it.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: O, thou hast damnable iteration, and art indeed able to corrupt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon me, Hal, God forgive thee for it! Before I knew thee, Hal, I knew nothing, and now am I, if a man should speak truly, little better than one of the wicked. I must give over this life, and I will give it over. By the Lord, and I do not, I am a villain, I’ll be damn’d for never a king’s son in Christendom.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Where shall we take a purse tomorrow, Jack?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Zounds, where thou wilt, lad, I’ll make one, an’ I do not, call me villain and baffle me.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I see a good amendment of life in thee, from praying to purse-taking.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Why, Hal, ’tis my vocation, Hal, ’tis no sin for a man to labor in his vocation.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Now, my good sweet honey lord, ride with us tomorrow. I have a jest to execute that I cannot manage alone. Falstaff, Bardolph, Peto, and Gadshill shall rob those men that we have already waylaid; yourself and I will not be there; and when they have the booty, if you and I do not rob them, cut this head off from my shoulders.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: How shall we part with them in setting forth?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Why, we will set forth before or after them and appoint them a place of meeting, wherein it is at our pleasure to fail; and then will they adventure upon the exploit themselves, which they shall have no sooner achiev’d but we’ll set upon them.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Yea, but ’tis like that they will know us by our horses, by our habits, and by every other appointment to be ourselves.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Tut, our horses they shall not see—I’ll tie them in the wood; our vizards we will change after we leave them; and, sirrah, I have cases of buckram for the nonce, to immask our noted outward garments.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Yea, but I doubt they will be too hard for us.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Well, for two of them, I know them to be as true-bred cowards as ever turn’d back; and for the third, if he fight longer than he sees reason, I’ll forswear arms. The virtue of this jest will be the incomprehensible lies that this same fat rogue will tell us when we meet at supper, how thirty at least he fought with, what wards, what blows, what extremities he endur’d, and in the reproof of this lives the jest.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Well, I’ll go with thee. Provide us all things necessary, and meet me tomorrow night in Eastcheap, there I’ll sup. Farewell.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Farewell, my lord.

stagedir.dir: Enter the King, Northumberland, Worcester, Hotspur, Sir Walter Blunt, with others.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Yea, my good lord.
Those prisoners in your Highness’ name demanded,
Which Harry Percy here at Holmedon took,
Were, as he says, not with such strength denied
As is delivered to your Majesty.
Either envy, therefore, or misprision
Is guilty of this fault, and not my son.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: My liege, I did deny no prisoners,
But I remember, when the fight was done,
When I was dry with rage and extreme toil,
Breathless and faint, leaning upon my sword,
Came there a certain lord, neat, and trimly dress’d,
Fresh as a bridegroom, and his chin new reap’d
Show’d like a stubble-land at harvest-home.
He was perfumed like a milliner,
And ’twixt his finger and his thumb he held
A pouncet-box, which ever and anon
He gave his nose and took’t away again,
Who therewith angry, when it next came there,
Took it in snuff—and still he smil’d and talk’d:
And as the soldiers bore dead bodies by,
He call’d them untaught knaves, unmannerly,
To bring a slovenly unhandsome corse
Betwixt the wind and his nobility.
With many holiday and lady terms
He questioned me, amongst the rest demanded
My prisoners in your Majesty’s behalf.
I then, all smarting with my wounds being cold,
To be so pest’red with a popingay,
Out of my grief and my impatience
Answer’d neglectingly, I know not what—
He should, or he should not—for he made me mad
To see him shine so brisk and smell so sweet,
And talk so like a waiting-gentlewoman
Of guns, and drums, and wounds, God save the mark!
And telling me the sovereignest thing on earth
Was parmaciti for an inward bruise,
And that it was great pity, so it was,
This villainous saltpetre should be digg’d
Out of the bowels of the harmless earth,
Which many a good tall fellow had destroyed
So cowardly, and but for these vile guns
He would himself have been a soldier.
This bald unjointed chat of his, my lord,
I answered indirectly, as I said,
And I beseech you, let not his report
Come current for an accusation
Betwixt my love and your high Majesty.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: The circumstance considered, good my lord,
What e’er Lord Harry Percy then had said
To such a person, and in such a place,
At such a time, with all the rest retold,
May reasonably die, and never rise
To do him wrong, or any way impeach
What then he said, so he unsay it now.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why, yet he doth deny his prisoners,
But with proviso and exception,
That we at our own charge shall ransom straight
His brother-in-law, the foolish Mortimer,
Who, on my soul, hath willfully betray’d
The lives of those that he did lead to fight
Against that great magician, damn’d Glendower,
Whose daughter, as we hear, that Earl of March
Hath lately married. Shall our coffers then
Be emptied to redeem a traitor home?
Shall we buy treason? And indent with fears,
When they have lost and forfeited themselves?
No, on the barren mountains let him starve;
For I shall never hold that man my friend
Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost
To ransom home revolted Mortimer.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Revolted Mortimer!
He never did fall off, my sovereign liege,
But by the chance of war; to prove that true
Needs no more but one tongue for all those wounds,
Those mouthed wounds, which valiantly he took,
When on the gentle Severn’s sedgy bank,
In single opposition hand to hand,
He did confound the best part of an hour
In changing hardiment with great Glendower.
Three times they breath’d and three times did they drink,
Upon agreement, of swift Severn’s flood,
Who then affrighted with their bloody looks,
Ran fearfully among the trembling reeds,
And hid his crisp head in the hollow bank,
Blood-stained with these valiant combatants.
Never did base and rotten policy
Color her working with such deadly wounds,
Nor never could the noble Mortimer
Receive so many, and all willingly.
Then let not him be slandered with revolt.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thou dost belie him, Percy, thou dost belie him;
He never did encounter with Glendower.
I tell thee,
He durst as well have met the devil alone
As Owen Glendower for an enemy.
Art thou not asham’d? But, sirrah, henceforth
Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer.
Send me your prisoners with the speediest means,
Or you shall hear in such a kind from me
As will displease you. My Lord Northumberland:
We license your departure with your son.
Send us your prisoners, or you will hear of it.

stagedir.dir: Exit King with Blunt and Train.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Speak of Mortimer!
’Zounds, I will speak of him, and let my soul
Want mercy if I do not join with him.
Yea, on his part I’ll empty all these veins,
And shed my dear blood drop by drop in the dust,
But I will lift the down-trod Mortimer
As high in the air as this unthankful king,
As this ingrate and cank’red Bullingbrook.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Brother, the King hath made your nephew mad.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Who strook this heat up after I was gone?

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: He will, forsooth, have all my prisoners,
And when I urg’d the ransom once again
Of my wive’s brother, then his cheek look’d pale,
And on my face he turn’d an eye of death,
Trembling even at the name of Mortimer.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: I cannot blame him: was not he proclaim’d
By Richard, that dead is, the next of blood?

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: He was, I heard the proclamation.
And then it was when the unhappy king
(Whose wrongs in us God pardon!) did set forth
Upon his Irish expedition;
From whence he intercepted did return
To be depos’d, and shortly murdered.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: And for whose death we in the world’s wide mouth
Live scandaliz’d and foully spoken of.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: But soft, I pray you, did King Richard then
Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer
Heir to the crown?

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: He did, myself did hear it.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Nay, then I cannot blame his cousin king,
That wish’d him on the barren mountains starve.
But shall it be that you, that set the crown
Upon the head of this forgetful man,
And for his sake wear the detested blot
Of murderous subornation—shall it be
That you a world of curses undergo,
Being the agents or base second means,
The cords, the ladder, or the hangman rather?
O, pardon me that I descend so low
To show the line and the predicament
Wherein you range under this subtle king!
Shall it for shame be spoken in these days,
Or fill up chronicles in time to come,
That men of your nobility and power
Did gage them both in an unjust behalf
(As both of you—God pardon it!—have done)
To put down Richard, that sweet lovely rose,
And plant this thorn, this canker, Bullingbrook?
And shall it in more shame be further spoken,
That you are fool’d, discarded, and shook off
By him for whom these shames ye underwent?
No, yet time serves wherein you may redeem
Your banish’d honors and restore yourselves
Into the good thoughts of the world again;
Revenge the jeering and disdain’d contempt
Of this proud king, who studies day and night
To answer all the debt he owes to you
Even with the bloody payment of your deaths.
Therefore I say—

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Peace, cousin, say no more.
And now I will unclasp a secret book,
And to your quick-conceiving discontents
I’ll read you matter deep and dangerous,
As full of peril and adventerous spirit
As to o’erwalk a current roaring loud
On the unsteadfast footing of a spear.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: If he fall in, good night, or sink or swim.
Send danger from the east unto the west,
So honor cross it from the north to south,
And let them grapple. O, the blood more stirs
To rouse a lion than to start a hare!

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Imagination of some great exploit
Drives him beyond the bounds of patience.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: By heaven, methinks it were an easy leap,
To pluck bright honor from the pale-fac’d moon,
Or dive into the bottom of the deep,
Where fathom-line could never touch the ground,
And pluck up drowned honor by the locks,
So he that doth redeem her thence might wear
Without corrival all her dignities;
But out upon this half-fac’d fellowship!

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: He apprehends a world of figures here,
But not the form of what he should attend.
Good cousin, give me audience for a while.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: I cry you mercy.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Those same noble Scots
That are your prisoners—

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: I’ll keep them all!
By God, he shall not have a Scot of them,
No, if a Scot would save his soul, he shall not!
I’ll keep them, by this hand.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: You start away,
And lend no ear unto my purposes.
Those prisoners you shall keep.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Nay, I will; that’s flat.
He said he would not ransom Mortimer,
Forbade my tongue to speak of Mortimer,
But I will find him when he lies asleep,
And in his ear I’ll holla “Mortimer!”
Nay,
I’ll have a starling shall be taught to speak
Nothing but “Mortimer,” and give it him
To keep his anger still in motion.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Hear you, cousin, a word.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: All studies here I solemnly defy,
Save how to gall and pinch this Bullingbrook,
And that same sword-and-buckler Prince of Wales,
But that I think his father loves him not
And would be glad he met with some mischance,
I would have him poisoned with a pot of ale.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Farewell, kinsman! I’ll talk to you
When you are better temper’d to attend.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Why, what a wasp-stung and impatient fool
Art thou to break into this woman’s mood,
Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own!

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Why, look you, I am whipt and scourg’d with rods,
Nettled and stung with pismires, when I hear
Of this vile politician, Bullingbrook.
In Richard’s time—what do you call the place?—
A plague upon it, it is in Gloucestershire—
’Twas where the madcap duke his uncle kept—
His uncle York—where I first bow’d my knee
Unto this king of smiles, this Bullingbrook—
’Sblood!
When you and he came back from Ravenspurgh—

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: At Berkeley castle.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: You say true.
Why, what a candy deal of courtesy
This fawning greyhound then did proffer me!
“Look when his infant fortune came to age”
And “gentle Harry Percy” and “kind cousin”—
O, the devil take such cozeners!—God forgive me!
Good uncle, tell your tale—I have done.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Nay, if you have not, to it again,
We will stay your leisure.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: I have done, i’ faith.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Then once more to your Scottish prisoners:
Deliver them up without their ransom straight,
And make the Douglas’ son your only mean
For powers in Scotland, which, for divers reasons
Which I shall send you written, be assur’d
Will easily be granted.

speech.speaker: 1. CAR.
speech.line: Heigh-ho! An’ it be not four by the day, I’ll be hang’d. Charles’ wain is over the new chimney, and yet our horse not pack’d. What, ostler!

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Anon, anon.

speech.speaker: 1. CAR.
speech.line: I prithee, Tom, beat Cut’s saddle, put a few flocks in the point. Poor jade is wrung in the withers, out of all cess.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: Good morrow, carriers, what’s a’ clock?

speech.speaker: 1. CAR.
speech.line: I think it be two a’ clock.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: I prithee lend me thy lantern, to see my gelding in the stable.

speech.speaker: 1. CAR.
speech.line: Nay, by God, soft, I know a trick worth two of that, i’ faith.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: I pray thee lend me thine.

speech.speaker: 2. CAR.
speech.line: Ay, when, canst tell? Lend me thy lantern, quoth he! Marry, I’ll see thee hang’d first.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: Sirrah carrier, what time do you mean to come to London?

speech.speaker: 2. CAR.
speech.line: Time enough to go to bed with a candle, I warrant thee. Come, neighbor Mugs, we’ll call up the gentlemen. They will along with company, for they have great charge.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: At hand, quoth pick-purse.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: That’s even as fair as—at hand, quoth the chamberlain; for thou variest no more from picking of purses than giving direction doth from laboring: thou layest the plot how.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Good morrow, Master Gadshill. It holds current that I told you yesternight: there’s a franklin in the Wild of Kent hath brought three hundred marks with him in gold. I heard him tell it to one of his company last night at supper, a kind of auditor, one that hath abundance of charge too—God knows what. They are up already, and call for eggs and butter. They will away presently.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: Sirrah, if they meet not with Saint Nicholas’ clerks, I’ll give thee this neck.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: No, I’ll none of it, I pray thee keep that for the hangman, for I know thou worshippest Saint Nicholas as truly as a man of falsehood may.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: What talkest thou to me of the hangman? If I hang, I’ll make a fat pair of gallows; for if I hang, old Sir John hangs with me, and thou knowest he is no starveling. Tut, there are other Troyans that thou dream’st not of, the which for sport sake are content to do the profession some grace, that would (if matters should be look’d into) for their own credit sake make all whole. I am join’d with no foot land-rakers, no long-staff sixpenny strikers, none of these mad mustachio purple-hu’d malt-worms, but with nobility and tranquility, burgomasters and great oney’rs, such as can hold in, such as will strike sooner than speak, and speak sooner than drink, and drink sooner than pray; and yet, ’zounds, I lie, for they pray continually to their saint, the commonwealth, or rather, not pray to her, but prey on her, for they ride up and down on her, and make her their boots.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: What, the commonwealth their boots? Will she hold out water in foul way?

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: She will, she will, justice hath liquor’d her. We steal as in a castle, cock-sure; we have the receipt of fern-seed, we walk invisible.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Nay, by my faith, I think you are more beholding to the night than to fern-seed for your walking invisible.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: Give me thy hand. Thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as I am a true man.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Nay, rather let me have it as you are a false thief.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: Go to, homo is a common name to all men. Bid the ostler bring my gelding out of the stable. Farewell, you muddy knave.

stagedir.dir: Enter Prince, Peto, and Bardolph, with Poins following just behind.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Poins! Poins, and be hang’d! Poins!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Peace, ye fat-kidney’d rascal! What a brawling dost thou keep!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Where’s Poins, Hal?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: He is walk’d up to the top of the hill, I’ll go seek him.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am accurs’d to rob in that thieve’s company. The rascal hath remov’d my horse, and tied him I know not where. If I travel but four foot by the squier further afoot, I shall break my wind. Well, I doubt not but to die a fair death for all this, if I scape hanging for killing that rogue. I have forsworn his company hourly any time this two and twenty years, and yet I am bewitch’d with the rogue’s company. If the rascal have not given me medicines to make me love him, I’ll be hang’d. It could not be else, I have drunk medicines. Poins! Hal! A plague upon you both! Bardolph! Peto! I’ll starve ere I’ll rob a foot further. And ’twere not as good a deed as drink to turn true man and to leave these rogues, I am the veriest varlet that ever chew’d with a tooth. Eight yards of uneven ground is threescore and ten miles afoot with me, and the stony-hearted villains know it well enough. A plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to another!
Whew! A plague upon you all! Give me my horse, you rogues, give me my horse, and be hang’d!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Peace, ye fat-guts, lie down. Lay thine ear close to the ground, and list if thou canst hear the tread of travellers.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Have you any levers to lift me up again, being down? ’Sblood, I’ll not bear my own flesh so far afoot again for all the coin in thy father’s exchequer. What a plague mean ye to colt me thus?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thou liest, thou art not colted, thou art uncolted.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I prithee, good prince—Hal!—help me to my horse, good king’s son.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Out, ye rogue! Shall I be your ostler?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Hang thyself in thine own heir-apparent garters! If I be ta’en, I’ll peach for this. And I have not ballads made on you all and sung to filthy tunes, let a cup of sack be my poison. When a jest is so forward, and afoot too! I hate it.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Here, hard by. Stand close.

speech.speaker: 1. TRAV.
speech.line: Come, neighbor, the boy shall lead our horses down the hill. We’ll walk afoot a while, and ease our legs.

speech.speaker: THIEVES.
speech.line: Stand!

speech.speaker: TRAVELLERS.
speech.line: Jesus bless us!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Strike! Down with them! Cut the villains’ throats! Ah, whoreson caterpillars! Bacon-fed knaves! They hate us youth. Down with them! Fleece them!

speech.speaker: 1. TRAV.
speech.line: O, we are undone, both we and ours forever!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Hang ye, gorbellied knaves, are ye undone? No, ye fat chuffs, I would your store were here! On, bacons, on! What, ye knaves, young men must live! You are grandjurors, are ye? We’ll jure ye, faith.

stagedir.dir: Here they rob them and bind them.
Enter the Prince and Poins in buckram.

speech.speaker: HOT.

line.recite: “But, for mine own part, my lord, I could be well contented to be there, in respect of the love I bear your house.”

speech.line: He could be contented: why is he not then? In the respect of the love he bears our house: he shows in this, he loves his own barn better than he loves our house. Let me see some more.
—why, that’s certain. ’Tis dangerous to take a cold, to sleep, to drink, but I tell you, my lord fool, out of this nettle, danger, we pluck this flower, safety.

line.recite: “The purpose you undertake is dangerous, the friends you have nam’d uncertain, the time itself unsorted, and your whole plot too light for the counterpoise of so great an opposition.”

speech.line: Say you so, say you so? I say unto you again, you are a shallow, cowardly hind, and you lie. What a lack-brain is this! By the Lord, our plot is a good plot as ever was laid, our friends true and constant: a good plot, good friends, and full of expectation; an excellent plot, very good friends. What a frosty-spirited rogue is this! Why, my Lord of York commends the plot and the general course of the action. ’Zounds, and I were now by this rascal, I could brain him with his lady’s fan. Is there not my father, my uncle, and myself? Lord Edmund Mortimer, my Lord of York, and Owen Glendower? Is there not besides the Douglas? Have I not all their letters to meet me in arms by the ninth of the next month? And are they not some of them set forward already? What a pagan rascal is this! An infidel! Ha, you shall see now in very sincerity of fear and cold heart will he to the King, and lay open all our proceedings. O, I could divide myself and go to buffets, for moving such a dish of skim-milk with so honorable an action! Hang him! Let him tell the King: we are prepar’d. I will set forward tonight.
How now, Kate? I must leave you within these two hours.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: O my good lord, why are you thus alone?
For what offense have I this fortnight been
A banish’d woman from my Harry’s bed?
Tell me, sweet lord, what is’t that takes from thee
Thy stomach, pleasure, and thy golden sleep?
Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth,
And start so often when thou sit’st alone?
Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks,
And given my treasures and my rights of thee
To thick-ey’d musing and curst melancholy?
In thy faint slumbers I by thee have watch’d,
And heard thee murmur tales of iron wars,
Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed,
Cry “Courage! To the field!” And thou hast talk’d
Of sallies and retires, of trenches, tents,
Of palisadoes, frontiers, parapets,
Of basilisks, of cannon, culverin,
Of prisoners’ ransom, and of soldiers slain,
And all the currents of a heady fight;
Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war,
And thus hath so bestirr’d thee in thy sleep,
That beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow,
Like bubbles in a late-disturbed stream,
And in thy face strange motions have appear’d,
Such as we see when men restrain their breath
On some great sudden hest. O, what portents are these?
Some heavy business hath my lord in hand,
And I must know it, else he loves me not.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: What ho!

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: But hear you, my lord.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: What say’st thou, my lady?

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: What is it carries you away?

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Why, my horse, my love, my horse.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Out, you mad-headed ape!
A weasel hath not such a deal of spleen
As you are toss’d with. In faith,
I’ll know your business, Harry, that I will.
I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir
About his title, and hath sent for you
To line his enterprise, but if you go—

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: So far afoot, I shall be weary, love.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Come, come, you paraquito, answer me
Directly unto this question that I ask.
In faith, I’ll break thy little finger, Harry,
And if thou wilt not tell me all things true.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Away,
Away, you trifler! Love, I love thee not,
I care not for thee, Kate. This is no world
To play with mammets and to tilt with lips.
We must have bloody noses and crack’d crowns,
And pass them current too. God’s me, my horse!
What say’st thou, Kate? What wouldst thou have with me?

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Do you not love me? Do you not indeed?
Well, do not then, for since you love me not,
I will not love myself. Do you not love me?
Nay, tell me if you speak in jest or no.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Come, wilt thou see me ride?
And when I am a’ horseback, I will swear
I love thee infinitely. But hark you, Kate,
I must not have you henceforth question me
Whither I go, nor reason whereabout.
Whither I must, I must, and to conclude,
This evening must I leave you, gentle Kate.
I know you wise, but yet no farther wise
Than Harry Percy’s wife; constant you are,
But yet a woman, and for secrecy,
No lady closer, for I well believe
Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know,
And so far will I trust thee, gentle Kate.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: How! So far?

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Not an inch further. But hark you, Kate,
Whither I go, thither shall you go too;
Today will I set forth, tomorrow you.
Will this content you, Kate?

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: It must of force.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Francis!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thou art perfect.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Francis!

speech.speaker: VINT.
speech.line: What, stand’st thou still, and hear’st such a calling? Look to the guests within.
Poins!

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Non, anon, sir.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Anon, anon, sir.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: That ever this fellow should have fewer words than a parrot, and yet the son of a woman! His industry is up stairs and down stairs, his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning. I am not yet of Percy’s mind, the Hotspur of the north, he that kills me some six or seven dozen of Scots at a breakfast, washes his hands, and says to his wife, “Fie upon this quiet life! I want work.” “O my sweet Harry,” says she, “how many hast thou kill’d today?” “Give my roan horse a drench,” says he, and answers, “Some fourteen,” an hour after; “a trifle, a trifle.” I prithee call in Falstaff. I’ll play Percy, and that damn’d brawn shall play Dame Mortimer his wife. “Rivo!” says the drunkard. Call in ribs, call in tallow.

stagedir.dir: Enter Falstaff, Gadshill, Bardolph, and Peto, Francis following with wine.

scene.line: A plague of all cowards, still say I.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What’s the matter! There be four of us here have ta’en a thousand pound this day morning.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Where is it, Jack? Where is it?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Where is it? Taken from us it is: a hundred upon poor four of us.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What, a hundred, man?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am a rogue if I were not at half-sword with a dozen of them two hours together. I have scap’d by miracle. I am eight times thrust through the doublet, four through the hose, my buckler cut through and through, my sword hack’d like a hand-saw—ecce signum! I never dealt better since I was a man; all would not do. A plague of all cowards! Let them speak; if they speak more or less than truth, they are villains and the sons of darkness.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Speak, sirs, how was it?

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: We four set upon some dozen—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Sixteen at least, my lord.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: And bound them.

speech.speaker: PETO.
speech.line: No, no, they were not bound.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You rogue, they were bound, every man of them, or I am a Jew else, a Hebrew Jew.

speech.speaker: GADS.
speech.line: As we were sharing, some six or seven fresh men set upon us—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And unbound the rest, and then come in the other.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What, fought you with them all?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: All? I know not what you call all, but if I fought not with fifty of them, I am a bunch of radish. If there were not two or three and fifty upon poor old Jack, then am I no two-legg’d creature.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Pray God you have not murd’red some of them.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Nay, that’s past praying for, I have pepper’d two of them. Two I am sure I have paid, two rogues in buckram suits. I tell thee what, Hal, if I tell thee a lie, spit in my face, call me horse. Thou knowest my old ward: here I lay, and thus I bore my point. Four rogues in buckram let drive at me—

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What, four? Thou saidst but two even now.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Four, Hal, I told thee four.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Ay, ay, he said four.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: These four came all afront, and mainly thrust at me. I made me no more ado but took all their seven points in my target, thus.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Seven? Why, there were but four even now.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: In buckram?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Ay, four, in buckram suits.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Seven, by these hilts, or I am a villain else.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Prithee let him alone, we shall have more anon.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Dost thou hear me, Hal?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Ay, and mark thee too, Jack.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Do so, for it is worth the list’ning to. These nine in buckram that I told thee of—

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: So, two more already.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Their points being broken—

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Down fell their hose.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Began to give me ground; but I follow’d me close, came in, foot and hand, and with a thought seven of the eleven I paid.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: O monstrous! Eleven buckram men grown out of two.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But, as the devil would have it, three misbegotten knaves in Kendal green came at my back and let drive at me, for it was so dark, Hal, that thou couldest not see thy hand.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: These lies are like their father that begets them, gross as a mountain, open, palpable. Why, thou clay-brain’d guts, thou knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson, obscene, greasy tallow-catch—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What, art thou mad? Art thou mad? Is not the truth the truth?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Why, how couldst thou know these men in Kendal green when it was so dark thou couldst not see thy hand? Come, tell us your reason; what sayest thou to this?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Come, your reason, Jack, your reason.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What, upon compulsion? ’Zounds, and I were at the strappado, or all the racks in the world, I would not tell you on compulsion. Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plentiful as blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon compulsion, I.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I’ll be no longer guilty of this sin. This sanguine coward, this bed-presser, this horse-back-breaker, this huge hill of flesh—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Sblood, you starveling, you eel-skin, you dried neat’s tongue, you bull’s pizzle, you stock-fish! O for breath to utter what is like thee! You tailor’s yard, you sheath, you bowcase, you vile standing tuck—

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Well, breathe a while, and then to it again, and when thou hast tir’d thyself in base comparisons, hear me speak but this—

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Mark, Jack.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: We two saw you four set on four and bound them, and were masters of their wealth. Mark now how a plain tale shall put you down. Then did we two set on you four, and with a word, outfac’d you from your prize, and have it, yea, and can show it you here in the house; and, Falstaff, you carried your guts away as nimbly, with as quick dexterity, and roar’d for mercy, and still run and roar’d, as ever I heard bull-calf. What a slave art thou to hack thy sword as thou hast done, and then say it was in fight! What trick? What device? What starting-hole? Canst thou now find out to hide thee from this open and apparent shame?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Come, let’s hear, Jack, what trick hast thou now?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: By the Lord, I knew ye as well as he that made ye. Why, hear you, my masters, was it for me to kill the heir-apparent? Should I turn upon the true prince? Why, thou knowest I am as valiant as Hercules; but beware instinct—the lion will not touch the true prince. Instinct is a great matter; I was now a coward on instinct. I shall think the better of myself, and thee, during my life; I for a valiant lion, and thou for a true prince. But by the Lord, lads, I am glad you have the money. Hostess, clap to the doors! Watch tonight, pray tomorrow. Gallants, lads, boys, hearts of gold, all the titles of good fellowship come to you! What, shall we be merry, shall we have a play extempore?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Content, and the argument shall be thy running away.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ah, no more of that, Hal, and thou lovest me!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O Jesu, my lord the Prince!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: How now, my lady the hostess! What say’st thou to me?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Marry, my lord, there is a nobleman of the court at door would speak with you. He says he comes from your father.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Give him as much as will make him a royal man, and send him back again to my mother.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What manner of man is he?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: An old man.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What doth gravity out of his bed at midnight? Shall I give him his answer?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Prithee do, Jack.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Faith, and I’ll send him packing.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Now, sirs, by’r lady, you fought fair, so did you, Peto, so did you, Bardolph. You are lions too, you ran away upon instinct, you will not touch the true prince, no, fie!

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Faith, I ran when I saw others run.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Faith, tell me now in earnest, how came Falstaff’s sword so hack’d?

speech.speaker: PETO.
speech.line: Why, he hack’d it with his dagger, and said he would swear truth out of England but he would make you believe it was done in fight, and persuaded us to do the like.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Yea, and to tickle our noses with speargrass to make them bleed, and then to beslubber our garments with it and swear it was the blood of true men. I did that I did not this seven year before, I blush’d to hear his monstrous devices.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: O villain, thou stolest a cup of sack eighteen years ago, and wert taken with the manner, and ever since thou hast blush’d extempore. Thou hadst fire and sword on thy side, and yet thou ran’st away; what instinct hadst thou for it?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: My lord, do you see these meteors? Do you behold these exhalations?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I do.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: What think you they portend?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Hot livers and cold purses.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Choler, my lord, if rightly taken.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: No, if rightly taken, halter. Here comes lean Jack, here comes bare-bone. How now, my sweet creature of bumbast, how long is’t ago, Jack, since thou sawest thine own knee?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My own knee? When I was about thy years, Hal, I was not an eagle’s talent in the waist, I could have crept into any alderman’s thumb-ring. A plague of sighing and grief, it blows a man up like a bladder. There’s villainous news abroad. Here was Sir John Bracy from your father; you must to the court in the morning. That same mad fellow of the north, Percy, and he of Wales that gave Amamon the bastinado and made Lucifer cuckold and swore the devil his true liegeman upon the cross of a Welsh hook—what a plague call you him?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: O, Glendower.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Owen, Owen, the same; and his son-in-law Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and that sprightly Scot of Scots, Douglas, that runs a’ horseback up a hill perpendicular—

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: He that rides at high speed and with his pistol kills a sparrow flying.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You have hit it.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: So did he never the sparrow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, that rascal hath good mettle in him, he will not run.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Why, what a rascal art thou then, to praise him so for running!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A’ horseback, ye cuckoo, but afoot he will not budge a foot.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Yes, Jack, upon instinct.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I grant ye, upon instinct. Well, he is there too, and one Mordake, and a thousand blue-caps more. Worcester is stol’n away tonight. Thy father’s beard is turn’d white with the news. You may buy land now as cheap as stinking mack’rel.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Why then, it is like, if there come a hot June and this civil buffeting hold, we shall buy maiden-heads as they buy hobnails, by the hundreds.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: By the mass, lad, thou sayest true, it is like we shall have good trading that way. But tell me, Hal, art not thou horrible afeard? Thou being heir-apparent, could the world pick thee out three such enemies again as that fiend Douglas, that spirit Percy, and that devil Glendower? Art thou not horribly afraid? Doth not thy blood thrill at it?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Not a whit, i’ faith, I lack some of thy instinct.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, thou wilt be horribly chid tomorrow when thou comest to thy father. If thou love me, practice an answer.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Do thou stand for my father and examine me upon the particulars of my life.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Shall I? Content. This chair shall be my state, this dagger my sceptre, and this cushion my crown.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Thy state is taken for a join’d-stool, thy golden sceptre for a leaden dagger, and thy precious rich crown for a pitiful bald crown!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, and the fire of grace be not quite out of thee, now shalt thou be mov’d. Give me a cup of sack to make my eyes look red, that it may be thought I have wept, for I must speak in passion, and I will do it in King Cambyses’ vein.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Well, here is my leg.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And here is my speech. Stand aside, nobility.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O Jesu, this is excellent sport, i’ faith!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Weep not, sweet queen, for trickling tears are vain.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O, the father, how he holds his countenance!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: For God’s sake, lords, convey my tristful queen,
For tears do stop the flood-gates of her eyes.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O Jesu, he doth it as like one of these harlotry players as ever I see!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Peace, good pint-pot, peace, good ticklebrain. Harry, I do not only marvel where thou spendest thy time, but also how thou art accompanied; for though the camomile, the more it is trodden on, the faster it grows, yet youth, the more it is wasted, the sooner it wears. That thou art my son I have partly thy mother’s word, partly my own opinion, but chiefly a villainous trick of thine eye, and a foolish hanging of thy nether lip, that doth warrant me. If then thou be son to me, here lies the point: why being son to me, art thou so pointed at? Shall the blessed sun of heaven prove a micher and eat blackberries? A question not to be ask’d. Shall the son of England prove a thief and take purses? A question to be ask’d. There is a thing, Harry, which thou hast often heard of, and it is known to many in our land by the name of pitch. This pitch (as ancient writers do report) doth defile, so doth the company thou keepest; for, Harry, now I do not speak to thee in drink, but in tears; not in pleasure, but in passion; not in words only, but in woes also. And yet there is a virtuous man whom I have often noted in thy company, but I know not his name.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What manner of man, and it like your Majesty?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A goodly portly man, i’ faith, and a corpulent, of a cheerful look, a pleasing eye, and a most noble carriage, and as I think, his age some fifty, or, by’r lady, inclining to threescore; and now I remember me, his name is Falstaff. If that man should be lewdly given, he deceiveth me; for, Harry, I see virtue in his looks. If then the tree may be known by the fruit, as the fruit by the tree, then peremptorily I speak it, there is virtue in that Falstaff; him keep with, the rest banish. And tell me now, thou naughty varlet, tell me, where hast thou been this month?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Dost thou speak like a king? Do thou stand for me, and I’ll play my father.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Depose me? If thou dost it half so gravely, so majestically, both in word and matter, hang me up by the heels for a rabbit-sucker or a poulter’s hare.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Well, here I am set.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And here I stand. Judge, my masters.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Now, Harry, whence come you?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My noble lord, from Eastcheap.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: The complaints I hear of thee are grievous.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Sblood, my lord, they are false.—Nay, I’ll tickle ye for a young prince, i’ faith.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Swearest thou, ungracious boy? Henceforth ne’er look on me. Thou art violently carried away from grace, there is a devil haunts thee in the likeness of an old fat man, a tun of man is thy companion. Why dost thou converse with that trunk of humors, that bolting-hutch of beastliness, that swoll’n parcel of dropsies, that huge bombard of sack, that stuff’d cloak-bag of guts, that roasted Manningtree ox with the pudding in his belly, that reverent Vice, that grey Iniquity, that father ruffian, that vanity in years? Wherein is he good, but to taste sack and drink it? Wherein neat and cleanly, but to carve a capon and eat it? Wherein cunning, but in craft? Wherein crafty, but in villainy? Wherein villainous, but in all things? Wherein worthy, but in nothing?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would your Grace would take me with you. Whom means your Grace?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: That villainous abominable misleader of youth, Falstaff, that old white-bearded Sathan.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, the man I know.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I know thou dost.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But to say I know more harm in him than in myself, were to say more than I know. That he is old, the more the pity, his white hairs do witness it, but that he is, saving your reverence, a whoremaster, that I utterly deny. If sack and sugar be a fault, God help the wicked! If to be old and merry be a sin, then many an old host that I know is damn’d. If to be fat be to be hated, then Pharaoh’s lean kine are to be lov’d. No, my good lord, banish Peto, banish Bardolph, banish Poins, but for sweet Jack Falstaff, kind Jack Falstaff, true Jack Falstaff, valiant Jack Falstaff, and therefore more valiant, being as he is old Jack Falstaff, banish not him thy Harry’s company, banish not him thy Harry’s company—banish plump Jack, and banish all the world.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I do, I will.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: O my lord, my lord, the sheriff with a most monstrous watch is at the door.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Out, ye rogue, play out the play, I have much to say in the behalf of that Falstaff.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O Jesu, my lord, my lord!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Heigh, heigh! The devil rides upon a fiddlestick. What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: The sheriff and all the watch are at the door, they are come to search the house. Shall I let them in?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Dost thou hear, Hal? Never call a true piece of gold a counterfeit. Thou art essentially made, without seeming so.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And thou a natural coward, without instinct.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I deny your major. If you will deny the sheriff, so, if not, let him enter. If I become not a cart as well as another man, a plague on my bringing up! I hope I shall as soon be strangled with a halter as another.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Go hide thee behind the arras, the rest walk up above. Now, my masters, for a true face and good conscience.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Both which I have had, but their date is out, and therefore I’ll hide me.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Call in the sheriff.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all except the Prince and Peto.

speech.line: Now, Master Sheriff, what is your will with me?

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: First, pardon me, my lord. A hue and cry
Hath followed certain men unto this house.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What men?

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: One of them is well known, my gracious lord,
A gross fat man.

speech.speaker: 1. CAR.
speech.line: As fat as butter.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: The man I do assure you is not here,
For I myself at this time have employ’d him.
And, sheriff, I will engage my word to thee
That I will by tomorrow dinner-time
Send him to answer thee, or any man,
For any thing he shall be charg’d withal,
And so let me entreat you leave the house.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: I will, my lord. There are two gentlemen
Have in this robbery lost three hundred marks.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: It may be so. If he have robb’d these men,
He shall be answerable, and so farewell.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Good night, my noble lord.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I think it is good morrow, is it not?

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Indeed, my lord, I think it be two a’ clock.

line.recite: Item, anchoves and sack after supper 2s. 6d.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: O monstrous! But one half-penny-worth of bread to this intolerable deal of sack! What there is else, keep close, we’ll read it at more advantage. There let him sleep till day. I’ll to the court in the morning. We must all to the wars, and thy place shall be honorable. I’ll procure this fat rogue a charge of foot, and I know his death will be a march of twelve score. The money shall be paid back again with advantage. Be with me betimes in the morning, and so good morrow, Pero.

speech.speaker: PETO.
speech.line: Good morrow, good my lord.

stagedir.dir: Enter Hotspur, Worcester, Lord Mortimer, Owen Glendower.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: Fie, cousin Percy, how you cross my father!

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: I cannot choose. Sometime he angers me
With telling me of the moldwarp and the ant,
Of the dreamer Merlin and his prophecies,
And of a dragon and a finless fish,
A clip-wing’d griffin and a moulten raven,
A couching lion and a ramping cat,
And such a deal of skimble-skamble stuff
As puts me from my faith. I tell you what:
He held me last night at least nine hours
In reckoning up the several devils’ names
That were his lackeys. I cried “hum,” and “well, go to,”
But mark’d him not a word. O, he is as tedious
As a tired horse, a railing wife,
Worse than a smoky house. I had rather live
With cheese and garlic in a windmill, far,
Than feed on cates and have him talk to me
In any summer house in Christendom.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: In faith, he is a worthy gentleman,
Exceedingly well read, and profited
In strange concealments, valiant as a lion,
And wondrous affable, and as bountiful
As mines of India. Shall I tell you, cousin?
He holds your temper in a high respect,
And curbs himself even of his natural scope
When you come ’cross his humor, faith, he does.
I warrant you, that man is not alive
Might so have tempted him as you have done,
Without the taste of danger and reproof.
But do not use it oft, let me entreat you.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: In faith, my lord, you are too willful-blame,
And since your coming hither have done enough
To put him quite besides his patience.
You must needs learn, lord, to amend this fault;
Though sometimes it show greatness, courage, blood—
And that’s the dearest grace it renders you—
Yet oftentimes it doth present harsh rage,
Defect of manners, want of government,
Pride, haughtiness, opinion, and disdain,
The least of which haunting a nobleman
Loseth men’s hearts and leaves behind a stain
Upon the beauty of all parts besides,
Beguiling them of commendation.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Well, I am school’d: good manners be your speed!
Here come our wives, and let us take our leave.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: This is the deadly spite that angers me:
My wife can speak no English, I no Welsh.

speech.speaker: GLEND.
speech.line: My daughter weeps, she’ll not part with you,
She’ll be a soldier too, she’ll to the wars.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: Good father, tell her that she and my aunt Percy
Shall follow in your conduct speedily.

stagedir.dir: Glendower speaks to her in Welsh, and she answers him in the same.

speech.speaker: GLEND.
speech.line: She is desperate here, a peevish self-will’d harlotry,
One that no persuasion can do good upon.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: I understand thy looks. That pretty Welsh
Which thou pourest down from these swelling heavens
I am too perfect in, and but for shame,
In such a parley should I answer thee.
I understand thy kisses, and thou mine,
And that’s a feeling disputation,
But I will never be a truant, love,
Till I have learn’d thy language, for thy tongue
Makes Welsh as sweet as ditties highly penn’d,
Sung by a fair queen in a summer’s bow’r,
With ravishing division, to her lute.

speech.speaker: GLEND.
speech.line: Nay, if you melt, then will she run mad.

stagedir.dir: The lady speaks again in Welsh.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: O, I am ignorance itself in this!

speech.speaker: GLEND.
speech.line: She bids you on the wanton rushes lay you down,
And rest your gentle head upon her lap,
And she will sing the song that pleaseth you,
And on your eyelids crown the god of sleep,
Charming your blood with pleasing heaviness,
Making such difference ’twixt wake and sleep
As is the difference betwixt day and night
The hour before the heavenly-harness’d team
Begins his golden progress in the east.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: With all my heart I’ll sit and hear her sing.
By that time will our book, I think, be drawn.

speech.speaker: GLEND.
speech.line: Do so,
And those musicians that shall play to you
Hang in the air a thousand leagues from hence,
And straight they shall be here. Sit and attend.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Come, Kate, thou art perfect in lying down.
Come, quick, quick, that I may lay my head in thy lap.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Go, ye giddy goose.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Now I perceive the devil understands Welsh,
And ’tis no marvel he is so humorous.
By’r lady, he is a good musician.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Then should you be nothing but musical, for you are altogether govern’d by humors. Lie still, ye thief, and hear the lady sing in Welsh.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: I had rather hear Lady, my brach, howl in Irish.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Wouldst thou have thy head broken?

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Then be still.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Neither, ’tis a woman’s fault.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: Now God help thee!

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: To the Welsh lady’s bed.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Peace, she sings.

stagedir.dir: Here the lady sings a Welsh song.

speech.speaker: GLEND.
speech.line: Come, come, Lord Mortimer, you are as slow
As hot Lord Percy is on fire to go.
By this our book is drawn, we’ll but seal,
And then to horse immediately.

speech.speaker: MORT.
speech.line: With all my heart.

stagedir.dir: Enter the King, Prince of Wales, Lords, and others.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Lords, give us leave, the Prince of Wales and I
Must have some private conference, but be near at hand,
For we shall presently have need of you.
How now, good Blunt? Thy looks are full of speed.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: So hath the business that I come to speak of.
Lord Mortimer of Scotland hath sent word
That Douglas and the English rebels met
The eleventh of this month at Shrewsbury.
A mighty and a fearful head they are,
If promises be kept on every hand,
As ever off’red foul play in a state.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: The Earl of Westmorland set forth today,
With him my son, Lord John of Lancaster,
For this advertisement is five days old.
On Wednesday next, Harry, you shall set forward,
On Thursday we ourselves will march. Our meeting
Is Bridgenorth. And, Harry, you shall march
Through Gloucestershire; by which account,
Our business valued, some twelve days hence
Our general forces at Bridgenorth shall meet.
Our hands are full of business, let’s away,
Advantage feeds him fat while men delay.

scene.line: How now, Dame Partlet the hen? Have you inquir’d yet who pick’d my pocket?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Why, Sir John, what do you think, Sir John? Do you think I keep thieves in my house? I have search’d, I have inquir’d, so has my husband, man by man, boy by boy, servant by servant. The tithe of a hair was never lost in my house before.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ye lie, hostess, Bardolph was shav’d, and lost many a hair, and I’ll be sworn my pocket was pick’d. Go to, you are a woman, go.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Who, I? No, I defy thee. God’s light, I was never call’d so in mine own house before.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Go to, I know you well enough.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: No, Sir John, you do not know me, Sir John. I know you, Sir John, you owe me money, Sir John, and now you pick a quarrel to beguile me of it. I bought you a dozen of shirts to your back.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Dowlas, filthy dowlas. I have given them away to bakers’ wives, they have made bolters of them.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Now as I am a true woman, holland of eight shillings an ell. You owe money here besides, Sir John, for your diet and by-drinkings, and money lent you, four and twenty pound.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: He had his part of it, let him pay.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: He? Alas, he is poor, he hath nothing.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: How? Poor? Look upon his face; what call you rich? Let them coin his nose, let them coin his cheeks. I’ll not pay a denier. What, will you make a younker of me? Shall I not take mine ease in mine inn but I shall have my pocket pick’d? I have lost a seal-ring of my grandfather’s worth forty mark.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O Jesu, I have heard the Prince tell him, I know not how oft, that that ring was copper!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: How? The Prince is a Jack, a sneak-up. ’Sblood, and he were here, I would cudgel him like a dog if he would say so.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Prince marching, with Peto, and Falstaff meets him playing upon his truncheon like a fife.

speech.line: Now, Hal, to the news at court for the robbery, lad, how is that answer’d?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: O, my sweet beef, I must still be good angel to thee. The money is paid back again.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: O, I do not like that paying back, ’tis a double labor.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I am good friends with my father and may do any thing.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Rob me the exchequer the first thing thou doest, and do it with unwash’d hands too.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Do, my lord.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I have procur’d thee, Jack, a charge of foot.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would it had been of horse. Where shall I find one that can steal well? O for a fine thief, of the age of two and twenty or thereabouts! I am heinously unprovided. Well, God be thank’d for these rebels, they offend none but the virtuous. I laud them, I praise them.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Bardolph!

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Go bear this letter to Lord John of Lancaster,
To my brother John; this to my Lord of Westmorland.
Jack, meet me tomorrow in the Temple Hall
At two a’ clock in the afternoon;
There shalt thou know thy charge, and there receive
Money and order for their furniture.
The land is burning, Percy stands on high,
And either we or they must lower lie.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Do so, and ’tis well.—
What letters hast thou there?—I can but thank you.

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: These letters come from your father.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Letters from him! Why comes he not himself?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: He cannot come, my lord, he is grievous sick.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: ’Zounds! How has he the leisure to be sick
In such a justling time? Who leads his power?
Under whose government come they along?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: His letters bears his mind, not I, my lord.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: I prithee tell me, doth he keep his bed?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: He did, my lord, four days ere I set forth,
And at the time of my departure thence
He was much fear’d by his physicians.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: I would the state of time had first been whole
Ere he by sickness had been visited,
His health was never better worth than now.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Sick now? Droop now? This sickness doth infect
The very life-blood of our enterprise,
’Tis catching hither, even to our camp.
He writes me here, that inward sickness—
And that his friends by deputation could not
So soon be drawn, nor did he think it meet
To lay so dangerous and dear a trust
On any soul remov’d, but on his own.
Yet doth he give us bold advertisement
That with our small conjunction we should on,
To see how fortune is dispos’d to us,
For, as he writes, there is no quailing now,
Because the King is certainly possess’d
Of all our purposes. What say you to it?

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Your father’s sickness is a maim to us.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: A perilous gash, a very limb lopp’d off—
And yet, in faith, it is not; his present want
Seems more than we shall find it. Were it good
To set the exact wealth of all our states
All at one cast? To set so rich a main
On the nice hazard of one doubtful hour?
It were not good, for therein should we read
The very bottom and the soul of hope,
The very list, the very utmost bound
Of all our fortunes.

speech.speaker: DOUG.
speech.line: Faith, and so we should,
Where now remains a sweet reversion,
We may boldly spend upon the hope of what
Is to come in.
A comfort of retirement lives in this.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: A rendezvous, a home to fly unto,
If that the devil and mischance look big
Upon the maidenhead of our affairs.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: But yet I would your father had been here.
The quality and hair of our attempt
Brooks no division. It will be thought
By some that know not why he is away
That wisdom, loyalty, and mere dislike
Of our proceedings kept the Earl from hence,
And think how such an apprehension
May turn the tide of fearful faction,
And breed a kind of question in our cause.
For well you know we of the off’ring side
Must keep aloof from strict arbitrement,
And stop all sight-holes, every loop from whence
The eye of reason may pry in upon us.
This absence of your father’s draws a curtain
That shows the ignorant a kind of fear
Before not dreamt of.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: You strain too far.
I rather of his absence make this use:
It lends a lustre and more great opinion,
A larger dare to our great enterprise,
Than if the Earl were here, for men must think,
If we without his help can make a head
To push against a kingdom, with his help
We shall o’erturn it topsy-turvy down.
Yet all goes well, yet all our joints are whole.

speech.speaker: DOUG.
speech.line: As heart can think. There is not such a word
Spoke of in Scotland as this term of fear.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Bardolph, get thee before to Coventry; fill me a bottle of sack. Our soldiers shall march through; we’ll to Sutton Co’fil’ tonight.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Will you give me money, captain?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Lay out, lay out.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: This bottle makes an angel.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And if it do, take it for thy labor, and if it make twenty, take them all, I’ll answer the coinage. Bid my lieutenant Peto meet me at town’s end.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: I will, captain, farewell.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: How now, blown Jack? How now, quilt?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What, Hal? How now, mad wag? What a devil dost thou in Warwickshire? My good Lord of Westmorland, I cry you mercy! I thought your honor had already been at Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Faith, Sir John, ’tis more than time that I were there, and you too, but my powers are there already. The King, I can tell you, looks for us all, we must away all night.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Tut, never fear me, I am as vigilant as a cat to steal cream.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I think, to steal cream indeed, for thy theft hath already made thee butter. But tell me, Jack, whose fellows are these that come after?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mine, Hal, mine.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I did never see such pitiful rascals.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Tut, tut, good enough to toss, food for powder, food for powder; they’ll fill a pit as well as better. Tush, man, mortal men, mortal men.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Ay, but, Sir John, methinks they are exceeding poor and bare, too beggarly.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Faith, for their poverty, I know not where they had that, and for their bareness, I am sure they never learn’d that of me.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: No, I’ll be sworn, unless you call three fingers in the ribs bare. But, sirrah, make haste, Percy is already in the field.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: We’ll fight with him tonight.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: It may not be.

speech.speaker: DOUG.
speech.line: You give him then advantage.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Not a whit.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Why say you so? Looks he not for supply?

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: So do we.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: His is certain, ours is doubtful.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Good cousin, be advis’d, stir not tonight.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Do not, my lord.

speech.speaker: DOUG.
speech.line: You do not counsel well,
You speak it out of fear and cold heart.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Do me no slander, Douglas. By my life,
And I dare well maintain it with my life,
If well-respected honor bid me on,
I hold as little counsel with weak fear
As you, my lord, or any Scot that this day lives.
Let it be seen tomorrow in the battle
Which of us fears.

speech.speaker: DOUG.
speech.line: Yea, or tonight.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Content.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Tonight, say I.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Come, come, it may not be. I wonder much,
Being men of such great leading as you are,
That you foresee not what impediments
Drag back our expedition. Certain horse
Of my cousin Vernon’s are not yet come up.
Your uncle Worcester’s horses came but today,
And now their pride and mettle is asleep,
Their courage with hard labor tame and dull,
That not a horse is half the half of himself.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: So are the horses of the enemy
In general journey-bated and brought low.
The better part of ours are full of rest.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: The number of the King exceedeth our.
For God’s sake, cousin, stay till all come in.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: I come with gracious offers from the King,
If you vouchsafe me hearing and respect.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt; and would to God
You were of our determination!
Some of us love you well, and even those some
Envy your great deservings and good name,
Because you are not of our quality,
But stand against us like an enemy.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: And God defend but still I should stand so,
So long as out of limit and true rule
You stand against anointed majesty.
But to my charge. The King hath sent to know
The nature of your griefs, and whereupon
You conjure from the breast of civil peace
Such bold hostility, teaching his duteous land
Audacious cruelty. If that the King
Have any way your good deserts forgot,
Which he confesseth to be manifold,
He bids you name your griefs, and with all speed
You shall have your desires with interest
And pardon absolute for yourself and these
Herein misled by your suggestion.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: The King is kind, and well we know the King
Knows at what time to promise, when to pay.
My father and my uncle and myself
Did give him that same royalty he wears,
And when he was not six and twenty strong,
Sick in the world’s regard, wretched and low,
A poor unminded outlaw sneaking home,
My father gave him welcome to the shore;
And when he heard him swear and vow to God
He came but to be Duke of Lancaster,
To sue his livery and beg his peace,
With tears of innocency and terms of zeal,
My father, in kind heart and pity mov’d,
Swore him assistance, and perform’d it too.
Now when the lords and barons of the realm
Perceiv’d Northumberland did lean to him,
The more and less came in with cap and knee,
Met him in boroughs, cities, villages,
Attended him on bridges, stood in lanes,
Laid gifts before him, proffer’d him their oaths,
Gave him their heirs as pages, followed him
Even at the heels in golden multitudes.
He presently, as greatness knows itself,
Steps me a little higher than his vow
Made to my father, while his blood was poor,
Upon the naked shore at Ravenspurgh,
And now forsooth takes on him to reform
Some certain edicts and some strait decrees
That lie too heavy on the commonwealth,
Cries out upon abuses, seems to weep
Over his country’s wrongs, and by this face,
This seeming brow of justice, did he win
The hearts of all that he did angle for;
Proceeded further—cut me off the heads
Of all the favorites that the absent King
In deputation left behind him here,
When he was personal in the Irish war.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: Tut, I came not to hear this.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Then to the point.
In short time after, he depos’d the King,
Soon after that, depriv’d him of his life,
And in the neck of that, task’d the whole state;
To make that worse, suff’red his kinsman March
(Who is, if every owner were well plac’d,
Indeed his king) to be engag’d in Wales,
There without ransom to lie forfeited;
Disgrac’d me in my happy victories,
Sought to entrap me by intelligence,
Rated mine uncle from the Council-board,
In rage dismiss’d my father from the court,
Broke oath on oath, committed wrong on wrong,
And in conclusion drove us to seek out
This head of safety, and withal to pry
Into his title, the which we find
Too indirect for long continuance.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: Shall I return this answer to the King?

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: Not so, Sir Walter; we’ll withdraw a while.
Go to the King, and let there be impawn’d
Some surety for a safe return again,
And in the morning early shall mine uncle
Bring him our purposes. And so farewell.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: I would you would accept of grace and love.

speech.speaker: HOT.
speech.line: And may be so we shall.

speech.speaker: BLUNT.
speech.line: Pray God you do.

stagedir.dir: Enter Archbishop of York, Sir Michael.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Hie, good Sir Michael, bear this sealed brief
With winged haste to the Lord Marshal,
This to my cousin Scroop, and all the rest
To whom they are directed. If you knew
How much they do import, you would make haste.

speech.speaker: SIR M.
speech.line: My good lord,
I guess their tenor.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Like enough you do.
Tomorrow, good Sir Michael, is a day
Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men
Must bide the touch; for, sir, at Shrewsbury,
As I am truly given to understand,
The King with mighty and quick-raised power
Meets with Lord Harry; and I fear, Sir Michael,
What with the sickness of Northumberland,
Whose power was in the first proportion,
And what with Owen Glendower’s absence thence,
Who with them was a rated sinew too,
And comes not in, overrul’d by prophecies,
I fear the power of Percy is too weak
To wage an instant trial with the King.

speech.speaker: SIR M.
speech.line: Why, my good lord, you need not fear,
There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: No, Mortimer is not there.

speech.speaker: SIR M.
speech.line: But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Harry Percy,
And there is my Lord of Worcester, and a head
Of gallant warriors, noble gentlemen.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: And so there is; but yet the King hath drawn
The special head of all the land together:
The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,
The noble Westmorland, and warlike Blunt,
And many more corrivals and dear men
Of estimation and command in arms.

speech.speaker: SIR M.
speech.line: Doubt not, my lord, they shall be well oppos’d.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: I hope no less, yet needful ’tis to fear,
And to prevent the worst, Sir Michael, speed;
For if Lord Percy thrive not, ere the King
Dismiss his power he means to visit us,
For he hath heard of our confederacy,
And ’tis but wisdom to make strong against him.
Therefore make haste. I must go write again
To other friends, and so farewell, Sir Michael.

scene.scenelocation: King Henry IV’s camp near Shrewsbury.

stagedir.dir: Enter the King, Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster, Sir Walter Blunt, Falstaff.
Enter Worcester and Sir Richard Vernon.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: It will not be accepted, on my life.
The Douglas and the Hotspur both together
Are confident against the world in arms.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Hence therefore, every leader to his charge,
For on their answer will we set on them,
And God befriend us as our cause is just!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Tis not due yet, I would be loath to pay him before his day. What need I be so forward with him that calls not on me? Well, ’tis no matter, honor pricks me on. Yea, but how if honor prick me off when I come on? How then? Can honor set to a leg? No. Or an arm? No. Or take away the grief of a wound? No. Honor hath no skill in surgery then? No. What is honor? A word. What is in that word honor? What is that honor? Air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it? He that died a’ Wednesday. Doth he feel it? No. Doth he hear it? No. ’Tis insensible then? Yea, to the dead. But will’t not live with the living? No. Why? Detraction will not suffer it. Therefore I’ll none of it, honor is a mere scutcheon. And so ends my catechism.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: O no, my nephew must not know, Sir Richard,
The liberal and kind offer of the King.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: ’Twere best he did.

speech.speaker: WOR.
speech.line: Then are we all undone;
It is not possible, it cannot be,
The King should keep his word in loving us.
He will suspect us still, and find a time
To punish this offense in other faults.
Supposition all our lives shall be stuck full of eyes,
For treason is but trusted like the fox,
Who never so tame, so cherish’d and lock’d up,
Will have a wild trick of his ancestors.
Look how we can, or sad or merrily,
Interpretation will misquote our looks,
And we shall feed like oxen at a stall,
The better cherish’d, still the nearer death.
My nephew’s trespass may be well forgot,
It hath the excuse of youth and heat of blood,
And an adopted name of privilege,
A hare-brain’d Hotspur, govern’d by a spleen.
All his offenses live upon my head
And on his father’s. We did train him on,
And his corruption being ta’en from us,
We as the spring of all shall pay for all.
Therefore, good cousin, let not Harry know,
In any case, the offer of the King.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Deliver what you will, I’ll say ’tis so.
Here comes your cousin.
